instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. No green light - powers on.
threads.message:
Hey,
So this is a fun one. I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> clean of liquid damage.
It originally came in with no green light, i gave the SMC a reflow and got the light back. happy days, ultrasonically cleaned, sent out, all working.

It came back a few days later with the same fault., knowing SMC's are not flip chip or real heat sensitive, i think maybe there is some bad pad wetting or something. I remove and reball the SMC. No dice. 
I replace the SMC with another pull, Same symptoms. 

8.6V is present (first thing i checked) 
PP3v42 is present
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> is present
I/O connector and cable are clean- the board has been tested with new replacements.
DC board has 3.4V on the centre pin, suggesting that both <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> have made it to the DCIN board with no issues.

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> has been replaced for good measure. 
Ive ran jumper wires to rebuild important traces to ensure there are no cracks in then traces. No symptom change at all. 

So here's whats confusing, all the signals are being generated and pulled up just fine, however the SMC isnt communicating with the charger. I have a feeling it has to be a bad ceramic 0201 capacitor in the SMC support circuit but that in itself is a rabbit hole. Anyone got any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. No green light - powers on.
threads.message: I have a feeling there is crap under J9500. ONEWIRE carries data and any resistance/capacitance on this line will cause corruption of the signal, having 3.3V on there is not proof it is working.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. No green light - powers on.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 7523"]I have a feeling there is crap under J9500. ONEWIRE carries data and any resistance/capacitance on this line will cause corruption of the signal, having 3.3V on there is not proof it is working.[/QUOTE]


Ive just replaced the connector, No dice. As stated it was clear from signs of liquid damage so i thought that connector failing would just be odd. 

Im yet to ultrasonic clean the flux of the connector witch may just get me there (ive had issues with SIO chips and flux before) but i somewhat doubt that will solve the issue. Any further thoughts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. No green light - powers on.
threads.message: Is <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> at 3.4V? Are you sure you are using the correct DCIN board and cable?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. No green light - powers on.
threads.message:
Yes <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is 3.4V 
Yes i am sure i am using the correct board and cable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. No green light - powers on.
threads.message: That pretty much only leaves an issue inside the PCB. What is diode mode and resistance to GND on the ONEWIRE bus?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. No green light - powers on.
threads.message: Ive tested it. Diode mode reads open (on an agilent <CHIP>U1252B</CHIP>) and the resistance to ground measures exactly the same as a known good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. No green light - powers on.
threads.message: Diode mode should not read open with red probe to GND and black to ONEWIRE, compare with working board or use different multimeter.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. No green light - powers on.
threads.message:
sorry, im new to diode mode measurements for diagnosis purposes, until recently i was using a old fluke 8840A bench meter with no diode setting. i had the probes the wrong way round lol. 

<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> measures 0.55 dead on a known good board.
it measure 0.5428 on the dead board 
But on a second known good board we get 0.5364.

I would suggest the data is insubstantial. 

<SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> measure 0.764 on a known good board
0.763 on the bad board.
0.762 on a second known good board.
Again i dont think that is giving me any clues.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. No green light - powers on.
threads.message: I honestly have no more clues. You can look at the data signal on the scope and compare with a working board. This may very well be a PCB issue on the ONEWIRE bus.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. No green light - powers on.
threads.message: Thanks Duke.  I've been having a similar issue (except my diodes to ground were ok), no green light.  I guess the DCIN's I was testing with were bad.  Found an old one I swear is no good by looks of it and turns out to be good.  Been at this one for days.
